newsitem.title: MALAYSIA: Malaysia's AMFB plans to expand.
newsitem.headline: Malaysia's AMFB plans to expand.

text.p: Arab-Malaysian Finance Bhd (AMFB) said on Monday it plans to open more branches and offer new services after being accorded a Tier-1 finance house by the central Bank Negara.

"We will want to do more of course but we will select the areas where we want to be. We cannot say exactly how many, but the more the better," AMFB chairman Azman Hashim told Reuters in a phone interview.
The company currently has 93 branches and is a market leader in second-hand car financing.
The Tier-1 status will also allow AMFB to open new branches without having to get prior approval from Bank Negara, unlike finance houses which do not have the Tier-1 status.

Under Malaysia's two-tier system, a finance house qualifies as a Tier-1 firm if it has shareholders' funds of at least 300 million ringgit. Funds must be doubled by end-1998, while minimum paid-up capital must reach at least 600 million by the year 2000.
Finance houses must also meet stringent requirements set by the central bank on capital adequacy, asset quality, management efficiency, earnings performance and liquidity performance.

AMFB said in a statement that Tier-1 status will allow it to provide services such as factoring, remittance service, and issuing of negotiable instruments of deposit up to five times the capital funds.
The status will also allow it to grant unsecured business loans up to a maximum of 500,000 ringgit and participating in venture capital financing and special funds established by the central bank.
For the year ended March 31, 1997, AMFB announced net profit of 251.67 million ringgit, a 39.2 percent jump over 180.69 million the previous year.
Azman declined to give an earnings growth forecast for the current year. "We are still expecting continuous growth but I can't tell you how many percent," he said.
Azman said he was confident that AMFB's "bread and butter" business of financing second-hand car loans remains healthy.
"We don't think car sales are slowing. In any case, most of our business are in the second-hand car business and that's still strong," he said.
